[[File:Nominalrealoilprices1968-2006.png|right|250px|thumb|The Real and Nominal price of oil from 1968 to 2006.<ref>[http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/aer/pdf/pages/sec5_50.pdf Annual Energy Review 2006], Energy Information Administration</ref>]] [[File:Oil price chronology-june2007.gif|450px|right|thumb|Detailed analysis of 1970–2007 changes in nominal oil price, unadjusted for inflation.]]
The '''1980s oil glut''' was a serious surplus of [[Petroleum|crude oil]] caused by falling demand following the [[1970s energy crisis]]. The world price of oil, which had peaked in 1980 at over [[United States dollar|US$]]35 per barrel (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|35|1980}} per barrel in 2008 dollars, when adjusted for inflation), fell in 1986 from $27 to below $10 (${{Inflation|US|27|1986}} to ${{Inflation|US|10|1986}} in 2008 dollars).<ref name="NYT"/><ref>{{cite news | title=Oil Prices Pass Record Set in ’80s, but Then Recede | date=2008-03-08 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/03/business/worldbusiness/03cnd-oil.html?hp | newspaper = New York Times | first=Jad | last=Mouawad | accessdate=2010-04-20}}</ref> The glut began in the early 1980s as a result of slowed economic activity in industrial countries (due to the crises of the 1970s, especially in [[1973 energy crisis|1973]] and [[1979 energy crisis|1979]]) and the energy conservation spurred by high fuel prices.<ref>{{cite news | title=Oil Glut, Price Cuts: How Long Will They Last?| journal=[[U.S. News & World Report]]| date= 1980-08-18| volume= 89 |issue = 7 | page= 44 }}</ref> The [[inflation]]-adjusted [[Real versus nominal value (economics)|real 2004 dollar value]] of oil fell from an average of $78.2 in 1981 to an average of $26.8 per barrel in 1986.<ref>[http://cta.ornl.gov/data/tedb26/Spreadsheets/Table10_03.xls Oak Ridge National Lab data]{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref>
In June 1981, ''[[The New York Times]]'' stated an "Oil glut! ... is here"<ref>{{cite news |title=How the Oil Glut Is Changing Business |newspaper=The New York Times |date=21 June 1981 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/business/how-the-oil-glut-is-changing-business.html?pagewanted=all |first=Robert D. |last=Hershey Jr.|accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref> and ''[[Time Magazine]]'' stated: "the world temporarily floats in a glut of oil",<ref name="Christopher Byron">{{cite news |title= Problems for Oil Producers | journal= Time | date= 1981-06-22 | url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,950550,00.html| first= Christopher | last= Byron| accessdate= 19 January 2008}}</ref> though the next week an article in ''The New York Times'' warned that the word "glut" was misleading, and that in reality, while temporary surpluses had brought down prices somewhat, prices were still well above pre-energy crisis levels.<ref>{{cite news | title=The Energy Outlook; Lulled to Sleep by the Oil Glut Mirage | newspaper= The New York Times | date= 1981-06-28 | first=Daniel | last=Yergin}}</ref> This sentiment was echoed in November 1981, when the CEO of [[Exxon Corp]] also characterized the glut as a temporary surplus, and that the word "glut" was an example of "our American penchant for exaggerated language". He wrote that the main cause of the glut was declining consumption. In the United States, Europe and Japan, oil consumption had fallen 13% from 1979 to 1981, due to "in part, in reaction to the very large increases in oil prices by the [[Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries]] and other oil exporters", continuing a trend begun during the 1973 price increases.<ref>{{cite journal |journal= Oil & Gas Journal |date=November 9, 1981 |title=The Oil Glut in Perspective |first=C. C., Jr. |last=Garvin |volume=Annual API Issue |page=151}}</ref>
After 1980, reduced demand and increased production produced a glut on the world market. The result was a six-year decline in the price of oil, which culminated by plunging more than half in 1986 alone.<ref name="NYT"/>
==Production== [[Image:Int oil2.gif|thumb|right|OPEC, Non-OPEC, & World oil production, 1973–2004<ref>[http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/international/contents.html EIA - International Energy Data and Analysis]</ref>]]
===Non-OPEC=== During the 1980s, reliance on [[Middle East]] production dwindled as commercial exploration developed major non-OPEC oilfields in Siberia, Alaska, the [[North Sea oil|North Sea]], and the Gulf of Mexico,<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1cJhK-Sd8QgC&pg=PT95 |title=American Power and the Prospects for International Order |first=Simon |last=Bromley |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |year=2013 |isbn=9780745658414 |page=95}}</ref> and the Soviet Union became the world's largest producer of oil.<ref>"World: Saudis Edge U.S. on Oil". ''Washington Post'', January 3, 1980, p. D2.</ref> Smaller non-OPEC producers including Brazil, Egypt, India, Malaysia, and Oman doubled their output between 1979 and 1985, to a total of 3 million barrels per day.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Lessons from the 1986 Oil Price Collapsey |first=Dermot |last=Gately |journal=Brookings Papers on Economic Activity |issue=2 |date=1986 |page=239 |url=http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/Projects/BPEA/1986-2/1986b_bpea_gately_adelman_griffin.PDF |access-date=2016-01-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509062905/http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/Projects/BPEA/1986-2/1986b_bpea_gately_adelman_griffin.PDF |archive-date=2016-05-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
====USA==== In April 1979, [[Jimmy Carter]] signed an executive order which was to remove [[price controls]] from petroleum products by October 1981, so that prices would be wholly determined by the free market. Carter's successor, [[Ronald Reagan]] signed an executive order on January 28, 1981, which enacted this reform immediately,<ref = Executive Order 12287>{{cite news | title=Executive Order 12287 -- Decontrol of Crude Oil and Refined Petroleum Products | date=January 28, 1981| url=http://www.reagan.utexas.edu/archives/speeches/1981/12881a.htm| accessdate= 9 July 2008}}</ref> allowing the [[free market]] to adjust oil prices in the US.<ref = Urban Transportation Planning>{{cite book |quote= "By September 30, 1981, petroleum prices were to be determined by the free market. This process was accelerated by President Reagan through an Executive Order"| title= Urban Transportation Planning in the United States An Historical Overview| first= Edward | last= Weiner | year=1999| publisher= Greenwood Publishing Group| page=112| url=https://books.google.com/?id=s9-53F2LN0UC&pg=PA112 |isbn= 978-0-275-96329-3 | accessdate= 7 June 2010}}</ref> This ended the withdrawal of old oil from the market and artificial scarcity, encouraging increased oil production.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} The US Oil [[Windfall profits tax]] was lowered in August 1981 and removed in 1988, ending disincentives to US oil producers. Additionally, [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System]] began pumping oil in 1977. The Alaskan [[Prudhoe Bay Oil Field]] entered peak production, supplying 2 million bpd of crude oil in 1988, 25 percent of all U.S. oil production.<ref>National Energy Technology Laboratory. "Fossil Energy - Alaska Oil History", Arctic Energy Office. Accessed July 29, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.netl.doe.gov/technologies/oil-gas/AEO/FossilEnergy/AlaskaOilHistory.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-29 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425181532/http://www.netl.doe.gov/technologies/oil-gas/AEO/FossilEnergy/AlaskaOilHistory.html |archivedate=2009-04-25 |df= }}</ref>
====North Sea==== Phillips Petroleum discovered oil in the [[Chalk Group#The North Sea|Chalk Group]] at [[Ekofisk]], in Norwegian waters in the central North Sea.<ref name="BP history">{{cite book|last1=Ferrier |first1=RW|last2=Bamberg |first2=JH|title=The History of the British Petroleum Company|publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1982 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=LVC0VlPOJxEC&pg=PA201 |isbn=978-0-521-78515-0|pages=201–3}}</ref> Discoveries increased exponentially in the 1970s and 1980s, and new fields were developed throughout the continental shelf.<ref name=vert2015-04>{{cite news|first=Kenneth I. |last=Swartz |url=http://www.verticalmag.com/news/article/31306 |title=Setting the Standard |work=Vertical Magazine |date=16 April 2015 |accessdate=18 April 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418013604/http://www.verticalmag.com/news/article/31306 |archive-date=2015-04-18 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===OPEC=== From 1980 to 1986, [[OPEC]] decreased oil production several times and nearly in half, in an attempt to maintain oil's high prices. However, it failed to hold on to its preeminent position, and by 1981, its production was surpassed by non-OPEC countries{{Clarify|date=April 2008}}. OPEC had seen its share of the world market drop to less than a third in 1985, from about half during the 1970s.<ref name="NYT" /> In February 1982, the ''[[Boston Globe]]'' reported that OPEC's production, which had previously peaked in 1977, was at its lowest level since 1969. Non-OPEC nations were at that time supplying most of the West's imports.<ref name="BoGlobe">{{cite news |title=The economy: the Oil Glut deepens; OPEC's grip loosens; but a boom or a bomb could spur prices back up| newspaper=Boston Globe| date=1982-02-28 | first=David | last=Warsh}}</ref>
OPEC's membership began to have divided opinions over what actions to take. In September 1985, [[Saudi Arabia]] became fed up with de facto propping up prices by lowering its own production in the face of high output from elsewhere in OPEC.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |first=Daniel |last=Yergin |title=[[The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power]] |publisher=Simon & Schuster |date=1991 |isbn=0-671-50248-4}}</ref> In 1985, daily output was around 3.5 million bpd, down from around 10 million in 1981.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> During this period, OPEC members were supposed to meet production quotas in order to maintain price stability; however, many countries inflated their reserves to achieve higher quotas, cheated, or outright refused to accord with the quotas.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> In 1985, the Saudis tired of this behavior and decided to punish the undisciplined OPEC countries.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The Saudis abandoned their role as [[swing producer]] and began producing at full capacity, creating a "huge surplus that angered many of their colleagues in OPEC".<ref name="TIME">{{cite news |title= Cheap Oil!| journal= Time | date= 1986-04-14 | url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,961087,00.html |first=Stephen |last=Koepp | accessdate= 19 January 2008}}</ref> [[EROEI|High-cost]] oil production facilities became less or even not profitable. Oil prices as a result fell to as low as $7 per barrel.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Reduced demand==
[[File:World energy consumption.svg|thumb|[[World energy consumption]], 1965–2013, showing oil demand falling significantly in the early 1980s]]
OPEC had relied on the [[price elasticity of demand|price inelasticity of demand]] of oil to maintain high consumption, but underestimated the extent to which other sources of supply would become profitable as prices increased. Electricity generation from [[coal]], [[nuclear power]] and [[natural gas]];<ref name=toth2006a>{{cite journal |title=Oil and nuclear power: Past, present, and future |first1=Ferenc L. |last1=Toth |first2=Hans-Holger |last2=Rogner |journal=Energy Economics |volume=28 |date=January 2006 |issue=1 |page=3 |url=http://www.iaea.org/OurWork/ST/NE/Pess/assets/oil+np_toth+rogner0106.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=4 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071203152254/http://www.iaea.org/OurWork/ST/NE/Pess/assets/oil%2Bnp_toth%2Brogner0106.pdf |archivedate=3 December 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> home heating from natural gas; and [[ethanol]] blended gasoline all reduced the demand for oil.
===USA=== New passenger [[Energy efficiency in transportation|car fuel economy]] in the US rose from 17 mpg in 1978 to more than 22 mpg in 1982, an increase of more than 30 percent.<ref> {{cite journal | first1 = Paul R. | last1 = Portney | first2 = Ian W.H. | last2 = Parry | first3 = Howard K. | last3 = Gruenspecht | first4 = Winston | last4 = Harrington | title = The Economics of Fuel Economy Standards | publisher = Resources For The Future | date= November 2003 | url = http://www.rff.org/documents/RFF-DP-03-44.pdf | accessdate= 4 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071201031917/http://www.rff.org/documents/RFF-DP-03-44.pdf| archivedate= 1 December 2007| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The US imported 28 percent of its oil in 1982 and 1983, down from 46.5 percent in 1977, due to lower consumption.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/30/business/worrying-anew-over-oil-imports.html?pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | first=Robert D. | last=Hershey Jr. | accessdate=2015-12-30 | title=Worrying Anew Over Oil Imports | date=1989-12-30}}</ref>
===Brazil=== {{Further information|History of ethanol fuel in Brazil}}
==Impact== [[Image:Opecrev.gif|thumb|right|Fluctuations of OPEC net oil export revenues since 1972<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/OPEC_Revenues/OPEC.html |title=OPEC Revenues Fact Sheet |publisher=US Energy Information Administration |date=January 10, 2006 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107014809/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/OPEC_Revenues/OPEC.html |archivedate=January 7, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.gov/beta/international/regions-topics.cfm?RegionTopicID=OPEC |title=OPEC Revenues Fact Sheet |publisher=U.S. Energy Information Administration |date=June 14, 2016 |accessdate=August 25, 2016}}</ref>]] The 1986 oil price collapse benefited oil-consuming countries such as the United States, Japan, Europe, and Third World nations, but represented a serious loss in revenue for oil-producing countries in [[northern Europe]], the [[Soviet Union]], and [[OPEC]].
In 1981, before the brunt of the glut, ''[[Time Magazine]]'' wrote that in general, "A glut of crude causes tighter development budgets" in some oil-exporting nations.<ref name="Christopher Byron"/> Mexico had [[Economic_history_of_Mexico#1982_crisis_and_recovery|an economic and debt crisis]] in 1982.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ruiz |first=Ramón Eduardo |authorlink=Ramón Eduardo Ruiz |date=2010 |title=Mexico: Why a Few are Rich and the People Poor |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T1BISuKDUS8C |location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, London |publisher=University of California Press |page=165 |isbn=0-520-26235-2 }}</ref> The Venezuelan economy contracted and [[inflation]] levels (consumer price inflation) rose, remaining between 6 and 12% from 1982 to 1986.<ref name=FTWD>{{cite book|last1=Heritage|first1=Andrew|title=Financial Times World Desk Reference|date=December 2002|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|isbn=9780789488053|pages=618–621}}<!--|accessdate=2 February 2015--></ref><ref name=inflation>[http://www.indexmundi.com/venezuela/inflation_rate_(consumer_prices).html "Venezuela Inflation rate (consumer prices)"]. Indexmundi. 2010. Retrieved 16 August 2010.</ref> Even Saudi Arabian economic power was significantly weakened.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}
Iraq had fought a long and costly [[Iran–Iraq War|war against Iran]], and had particularly weak revenues<!-- obviously had weak revenues in 1986 if it relies on oil exports, so something needs to make the last part of that statement worth mentioning -->. It was upset by [[Kuwait]] contributing to the glut <!-- how did K. contribute to the glut? --><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.nmhschool.org/tthornton/mehistorydatabase/gulf_war.php |title=The Gulf Wars: Iraq Occupies Kuwait |publisher=Northfield Mount Hermon School |date=2007-01-12 |first=Ted |last=Thornton |accessdate=14 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217234053/http://www.nmhschool.org/tthornton/mehistorydatabase/gulf_war.php |archivedate=17 December 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and allegedly pumping oil from the [[Rumaila field]] below their common border.<ref name="Rousseau"> {{cite web |url=http://www.cnr.vt.edu/lsg/intro/oil.pdf |title=History of OPEC |publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania]] |date=1998 |first=David L. |last=Rousseau |format=PDF |accessdate=12 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227032238/http://www.cnr.vt.edu/lsg/intro/oil.pdf |archivedate=27 February 2008 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Iraq [[Invasion of Kuwait|invaded Kuwait in 1990]], planning to increase reserves and revenues and cancel the debt, resulting in the first [[Gulf War]].<ref name="Rousseau"/>
The USSR had become a major oil producer before the glut. The drop of oil prices contributed to [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|the nation's final collapse]].<ref>{{cite web |title=The Soviet Collapse: Grain and Oil |authorlink=Yegor Gaidar |first=Yegor |last=Gaidar |publisher=[[American Enterprise Institute]] |date=April 2007 |url=https://www.aei.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/20070419_Gaidar.pdf |quote=Oil production in Saudi Arabia increased fourfold, while oil prices collapsed by approximately the same amount in real terms. As a result, the Soviet Union lost approximately $20 billion per year, money without which the country simply could not survive.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The Economics Behind the Fall of the Berlin Wall |first=Ryan |last=McMaken |publisher=[[Mises Institute]] |date=7 November 2014 |url=https://mises.org/library/economics-behind-fall-berlin-wall |quote=High oil prices in the 1970s propped up the regime so well, that had it not been for Soviet oil sales, it’s quite possible the regime would have collapsed a decade earlier.}}</ref>
In the US, domestic exploration and the number of active drilling rigs were cut dramatically. In late 1985, there were nearly 2,300 rigs drilling wells in the USA; a year later, there were barely 1,000.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gold |first=Russell |authorlink=Russell Gold|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/back-to-the-future-oil-replays-1980s-bust-1421196361l |work=Wall Street Journal |title=Back to the Future? Oil Replays 1980s Bust |date=2015-01-13 |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> The number of petroleum producers in United States decreased from 11,370 in 1985 to 5,231 in 1989, according to data from the [[Independent Petroleum Association of America]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Penty |first1=Rebecca |last2=Shauk |first2=Zain |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-01-21/crude-collapse-has-investors-braced-for-80s-like-oil-casualties |work=Bloomberg |title=Crude Collapse Has Investors Braced for ’80s-Like Oil Casualties |date=2015-01-21 |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> Oil producers held back on the search for new oilfields for fear of losing on their investments.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/home/free_forbes/2006/0724/042.html |work=Forbes |title=Oil, Oil Everywhere |date=2006-07-24 |accessdate=6 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108013346/http://www.forbes.com/home/free_forbes/2006/0724/042.html |archivedate=8 January 2008 |deadurl=no}}</ref> In May 2007, companies like [[ExxonMobil]] were not making nearly the investment in finding new oil that they did in 1981.<!-- does this have to do with the oil glut??? --><ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1626994,00.html |title=No More Gushers for ExxonMobil |journal=Time |first=Justin |last=Fox |authorlink=Justin Fox |date=2007-05-31 |accessdate=8 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080113233033/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C1626994%2C00.html |archivedate=13 January 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Canada responded to high energy prices in the 1970s with the [[National Energy Program]] (NEP) in 1980. This program was in place until 1985.
==See also== *[[1980–89 world oil market chronology]] *[[2010s oil glut]]

{{Infobox person |name = Brendan Blumer |image = Brendan Blumer.jpg |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1986|8|8}} |birth_place = [[Cedar Rapids, Iowa]] |residence = [[Hong Kong]] |nationality = [[United States|American]] |known_for = [[EOS.IO]] | net_worth = {{nowrap| [[US$]]600–700 million<ref name="pamelaambler" />}} (Feb. 2018) | title = {{ubl|CEO of Block.one}} | boards = {{ubl|Block.one}} |footnotes = }}
'''Brendan Blumer''' (born August 8, 1986) is an American [[entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]], executive, and investor. He is the CEO of Block.one, the tech company producing the [[EOS.IO]] distributed ledger software. He is based in [[Hong Kong]].<ref name="pamelaambler">{{cite web |last=Ambler |first=Pamela |work= [[Forbes]] |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamelaambler/2018/02/07/brendan-blumer-block-eos-crypto-cryptocurrency/ |title= Ethereum Challenger Brendan Blumer Breaks Biggest Token Sale Record With EOS |date= 7 February 2018 |accessdate= 24 May 2018}}</ref>
== Early life == Blumer was born and raised in [[Cedar Rapids, Iowa]].<ref name=paulvigna>{{cite web |last=Vigna |first=Paul |work= [[Wall Street Journal]] |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/chasing-the-next-bitcoin-investors-shell-out-700-million-for-coins-with-no-purpose-1513602000 |title= Chasing the Next Bitcoin, Investors Shell Out $700 Million for Coins With 'No Purpose' |date= 18 December 2018 |accessdate= 24 May 2018}}</ref> When he was 15 years old, he developed a website to sell [[virtual economy|virtual assets]] in the [[multiplayer online gaming]] space. His website, known as Gamecliff (stylized as ''GaMeCliff''),<ref name=katharinecarlon>{{cite web |last=Carlon |first=Katharine |work= Corridor Business |url= https://mixergy.com/interviews/brendan-blumer-accounts-ne-interview/ |title= CR native is building the future, block by block |date= 9 January 2018 |accessdate= 24 May 2018}}</ref> displayed different characters, weapons, and houses for [[MMORPG]] games including [[EverQuest]] and [[World of Warcraft]].<ref name="pamelaambler" />
== Career == {{list|date=November 2018}} In 2005, Blumer's Gamecliff was acquired by [[IGE]].<ref name="dianabruk">{{cite web |last=Bruk |first=Diana |work= [[Best Life]] |url= https://bestlifeonline.com/10-cryptocurrency-millionaires-40/ |title= Here Are the 10 Wealthiest Cryptomillionaires Under 40 |date= 7 February 2018 |accessdate= 24 May 2018}}</ref> The company moved to its new headquarters to [[Hong Kong]] to head Gamecliff's operations.<ref name=pamelaambler>{{cite web |last=Ambler |first=Pamela |work= [[Forbes]] |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamelaambler/2018/02/07/brendan-blumer-block-eos-crypto-cryptocurrency/ |title= Ethereum Challenger Brendan Blumer Breaks Biggest Token Sale Record With EOS |date= 7 February 2018 |accessdate= 24 May 2018}}</ref>
In 2007, Blumer founded The Accounts Network, a company that sold in-game MMORPG [[avatar (computing)|avatars]].<ref name=andrewwarner>{{cite web |last=Warner |first=Andrew |work= Mixergy |url= https://mixergy.com/interviews/brendan-blumer-accounts-ne-interview/ |title= At 15, He Sold Game Avatars. Today, He's Selling Asia |date= 9 August 2011 |accessdate= 24 May 2018}}</ref>
In 2010, Blumer launched Okay.com, an enterprise [[data sharing]] platform for [[real estate brokers]] in Asia.<ref name="pamelaambler" /> The company later merged with the real estate company Asia Pacific Properties.<ref name=APP>{{cite web|work= Asia Pacific Properties |url= http://www.asiapacificproperties.com/corporate-news/archive-news/26/312/asia-pacific-properties-acquired-a-leading-real-estate-technology-company.html |title= Asia Pacific Properties Acquired a Leading Real Estate Technology Company |date= 2011 |accessdate= 24 May 2018}}</ref>
He founded ii5 in 2013, a startup dedicated to real-estate listings in [[India]].<ref name="paulvigna" />
In 2016, Brendan Blumer met software programmer [[Daniel Larimer]].<ref name="pamelaambler" /> In March 2017, Blumer and Larimer together formed Block.One, an [[open source software]] publishing company specializing in high performance [[blockchain]] technologies.<ref name="paulvigna" />
In May 2017, Blumer and Larimer announced their first project, [[EOS.IO]].<ref name=danlarimer>{{cite web |last=Larimer |first=Dan |work= YouTube |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MUZWZj1pu94 |title= EOS Consensus Presentation May 2017 |date= 5 June 2017 |accessdate= 24 May 2018}}</ref> Critics have argued that Block.one's year long EOS initial coin offering (ICO) is unnecessarily aggressive in the amount of funds that it is seeking to raise for such a product.<ref name="paulvigna" />
In February 2018, he was recognized by ''Forbes'' as one of "The Richest People In Cryptocurrency".<ref name="forbes">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/richest-in-cryptocurrency/|title=The Richest People In Cryptocurrency|date=6 February 2018|work=Forbes|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref>

{{Infobox company| name = Bronner Bros. | logo = | type = [[Private company|Private]]| foundation = 1947 | location = [[Marietta, Georgia]] 30336
revenue = {{profit}} [[United States dollar|US$]]38 million (2004)[http://www.bronnerbros.com/html/media/2_theformula.html The Formula - Bronner Bros] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020122842/http://www.bronnerbros.com/html/media/2_theformula.html |date=October 20, 2007 }} | num_employees = 300 | products = African American hair and skin care products | homepage = [http://www.bronnerbros.com/ www.bronnerbros.com] }} The '''Bronner Bros.''' Enterprise is one of the largest private [[African American]] hair and skin care producers in the United States. Founded in 1947{{cite web|title=Bronner Bros. History |url=http://www.bronnerbros.com/html/history.html |accessdate=2007-10-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071002111708/http://www.bronnerbros.com/html/history.html |archivedate=2007-10-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }} by brothers Dr. Nathaniel H. Bronner, Sr. and Arthur E. Bronner, Sr., Bronner Bros. has over 300 full-time and part-time staff members. The company headquarters is located in [[Marietta, Georgia]]. == History == [[Image:Show pic1.jpg|140px|thumb|Behind the scenes at one of the Bronner Bros. trade shows]]Nathaniel and Arthur Bronner, with the help of their sister, Emma Bronner, started Bronner Bros. in 1947 as a way to teach [[cosmetology]] at the local [[YMCA]]. About 300 people attended the first show but as the attendance grew, it was moved to the Royal Peacock Social Club and then to the Auburn Avenue Casino.{{cite news|last1=Thomas|first1=Chandra|title=Cutting Edge|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=qg4AAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA163&lpg=PA163&dq=The+Ark+of+Salvation+bronner&source=bl&ots=XsP7zOvMmh&sig=a_AADYNpz3xV4FB808be3UimmwQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwin2vDz-PbRAhXFBcAKHQLwAlMQ6AEITDAJ#v=onepage&q=The%20Ark%20of%20Salvation%20bronner&f=false|accessdate=4 February 2017|agency=Atlanta|date=September 2007}} In 1967, Bronner Bros. signed a contract with the new [[Hyatt Regency Hotel]] and the show was on that gas held there annually for the next 20 years. During this time, the Bronners secured a number of popular guest speakers, including Dr. [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]], [[Jackie Robinson]], [[Dick Gregory]] and Dr. [[Benjamin Mays]].{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://bronnerbros.com/our-history/|website=BronnerBros.com|accessdate=4 February 2017}} With Nathaniel Bronner, Sr's death in 1993, Bernard Bronner took over the company as president and CEO and the trade show has continued to grow by leaps and bounds. In 1996, all Bronner Bros. delegates traveled to [[Orlando, Florida]] for a large conference. The annual trade show is now held in the prestigious [[Georgia World Congress Center]]. As of 2015, the Bronner Bros. International Beauty Show was the largest gathering of multicultural beauty professionals in the U.S., pulling in 22,000 attendees and 300 exhibitors.{{cite web|last1=Whaley|first1=Kacie|title=2015 Bronner Bros. International Beauty Show to be bigger and better than ever|url=http://rollingout.com/2015/08/12/2015-bronner-bros-beauty-show-bigger-better-ever/|website=Rollingout.com|accessdate=4 February 2017|date=12 August 2015}} More and more Bronner family members are getting involved in the company. There were two brothers in the first generation of the business, six brothers in the second generation, the third generation now has 30 members.{{cite web|title=2004 Annual Report For Walmart Stores Inc|url=https://archive.org/stream/2004-annual-report-for-walmart-stores-inc/2004-annual-report-for-walmart-stores-inc_djvu.txt|website=Archive.org|accessdate=4 February 2017}} Bernard Bronner was also a partner in [[Rainforest Films]], which produced films targeting an urban audience and featuring African-American talent, until the company was formally dissolved in 2014.{{cite web|last1=Yamato|first1=Jen|title=‘Think Like A Man Too’ Producers Dissolve Hitmaking Shingle Rainforest Films|url=http://deadline.com/2014/06/think-like-a-man-too-will-packer-rob-hardy-dissolve-rainforest-films-794948/|website=Deadline.com|accessdate=4 February 2017}} Rainforest's filmography includes ''[[Stomp the Yard]]'', ''[[The Gospel (film)|The Gospel]]'', ''[[Trois 2: Pandora's Box|Pandora's Box]]'', ''[[This Christmas (film)|This Christmas]]'', and ''[[Takers]]''. == Bronner Bros. products == [[Image:Pump it up product.gif|100px|thumb|Pump It Up is just one of the products made by Bronner Bros.]] Bronner Bros. products are created primarily for the African-American population. Their main product lines include African Royale, BB, and NuExpressions. Bronner Bros. owns and operates two manufacturing facilities, a shipping facility, two beauty stores, a [[hair weaving]] studio and a Public Relations office. == Christian organizations == [[Image:Word of faith.jpg|300px|thumb|right|The Word of Faith Family Worship Cathedral]]Bronner Bros. has not been quiet when it comes to the company's Christian beliefs. One of their most successful organizations is The [[Word of Faith]] Family Worship Cathedral in [[Austell, Georgia]], founded by Bishop Dale C. Bronner the son of Nathaniel Bronner (one of the Bronner Bros. founders).{{cite web|title=About Us - Bishop Dale C. Bronner|url=http://www.woffamily.org/about-us/bishop-dale-c-bronner/|website=WofFamily.org|accessdate=4 February 2017}} The ministry has more than 19,000 members and over five branch ministries which it has birthed. Under the motto "Reaching the lost, teaching the found," the center provides a number of ministries, including [[Christian education]], Sunday school classes, singles [[Religious ministry (Christian)|ministry]], marriage ministry, prison ministry and the Bronner Business Institute which provides training for those who want to become entrepreneurs. The ministry currently run a school for infant to preschool children called the Seeds of Excellence Christian Academy in [[Austell, Georgia]], blocks away from the Cathedral.{{cite web|title=Information for Seeds of Excellence Christian Academy|url=http://childcarecenter.us/provider_detail/seeds_of_excellence_christian_academy_austell_ga|website=ChildCareCenter.us|accessdate=4 February 2017}} Word of Faith recently built a recreation center called The Family Life Center.{{Cite web|url=http://www.poharchitects.com/rec_wof_life_center.html|title=Pieper O'Brien Herr Architects|last=|first=|date=January 5, 2018|website=Pieper O'Brien Herr Architects|archive-url=http://www.poharchitects.com/rec_wof_life_center.html|archive-date=January 5, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=January 5, 2018}} The Bronner family also founded The Ark of Salvation Worship Center in [[Atlanta|Atlanta, GA]], which Rev. '''''Manihot esculenta''''', [[common name|commonly called]] '''cassava''' ({{IPAc-en|k|ə|ˈ|s|ɑː|v|ə}}), '''manioc''',<ref name=GRIN>{{GRIN |accessdate=4 January 2014}}</ref> '''yuca''', '''macaxeira''', '''mandioca''', '''aipim''' and '''Brazilian arrowroot''',{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} is a woody [[shrub]] native to South America of the [[spurge]] family, [[Euphorbiaceae]]. It is extensively cultivated as an annual [[agriculture|crop]] in [[tropical]] and [[subtropical]] regions for its edible [[starch]]y [[tuberous root]], a major source of [[carbohydrate]]s. Though it is often called '''''yuca''''' in Spanish and in the United States, it differs from [[yucca]], an unrelated fruit-bearing shrub in the family [[Asparagaceae]]. Cassava, when dried to a powdery (or pearly) extract, is called [[tapioca]]; its fried, granular form is named ''[[garri]]''.
Cassava is the third-largest source of food carbohydrates in the tropics, after [[rice]] and [[maize]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Cassava|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/agpc/gcds/}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Fauquet Claude |author2=Fargette Denis | year = 1990 | title = African Cassava Mosaic Virus: Etiology, Epidemiology, and Control | url = http://www.apsnet.org/publications/PlantDisease/BackIssues/Documents/1990Articles/PlantDisease74n06_404.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Plant Disease | volume = 74 | issue = 6| pages = 404–11 | doi=10.1094/pd-74-0404}}</ref> Cassava is a major [[staple food]] in the developing world, providing a basic diet for over half a billion people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dimensions of Need: An atlas of food and agriculture |publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|year=1995|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/u8480e/U8480E01.htm}}</ref> It is one of the most drought-tolerant crops, capable of growing on marginal soils. Nigeria is the world's largest producer of cassava, while Thailand is the largest exporter of dried cassava.
Cassava is classified as either sweet or bitter. Like other roots and tubers, both bitter and sweet varieties of cassava contain [[antinutrient|antinutritional]] factors and toxins, with the bitter varieties containing much larger amounts.<ref name="fao.org">{{cite book|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations |year=1990|title=Roots, tubers, plantains and bananas in human nutrition|chapter= Ch. 7 Toxic substances and antinutritional factors|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/t0207e/T0207E08.htm#Cassava%20toxicity |place=Rome|isbn=9789251028629}}</ref> It must be properly prepared before consumption, as improper preparation of cassava can leave enough residual [[cyanide]] to cause acute [[cyanide poisoning|cyanide intoxication]],<ref name="promedmail-4799579">{{cite web|url=https://www.promedmail.org/post/4799579|title=CASSAVA POISONING – VENEZUELA|date=29 January 2017|access-date=29 January 2017|publisher=[[ProMED-mail]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cassava poisoning was integral to Episode 177 of Series 17 of the BBC drama 'Doctors' |publisher=BBC|date=5 February 2016 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b06zn3j8/doctors-series-17-177-a-taste-of-home}}</ref> [[goiter]]s, and even [[ataxia]], partial paralysis, or death. The more toxic varieties of cassava are a fall-back resource (a "[[food security]] crop") in times of famine or food insecurity in some places.<ref name="promedmail-4799579" /><ref name="fao.org"/> Farmers often prefer the bitter varieties because they deter pests, animals, and thieves.<ref name="leisa">{{cite journal|author=Chiwona-Karltun, Linley; Katundu, Chrissie; Ngoma, James; Chipungu, Felistus; Mkumbira, Jonathan; Simukoko, Sidney and Jiggins, Janice |year=2002|title=Bitter cassava and women: an intriguing response to food security|journal=LEISA Magazine| volume =18 |issue =4|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/255687456}}</ref>
==Description== The cassava root is long and tapered, with a firm, homogeneous flesh encased in a detachable rind, about 1 mm thick, rough and brown on the outside. Commercial [[cultivar]]s can be {{convert|5|to|10|cm|abbr=on}} in diameter at the top, and around {{convert|15|to|30|cm|abbr=on}} long. A woody vascular bundle runs along the root's [[Coordinate axis|axis]]. The flesh can be chalk-white or yellowish. Cassava roots are very rich in [[starch]] and contain small amounts of calcium (16 mg/100 g), phosphorus (27 mg/100 g), and vitamin C (20.6 mg/100 g).<ref>{{cite web|title=Basic Report: 11134, Cassava, raw|url=https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/foods/show/2907?manu=&fgcd=&ds=|website=National Nutrient Database for Standard Reference Release 28|date=May 2016|publisher=Agricultural Research Service, US Department of Agriculture|accessdate=7 December 2016}}</ref> However, they are poor in [[protein]] and other [[nutrient]]s. In contrast, cassava leaves are a good source of protein (rich in lysine), but deficient in the [[amino acid]] [[methionine]] and possibly [[tryptophan]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Ravindran |first=Velmerugu|title=Preparation of cassava leaf products and their use as animal feeds. |journal=FAO Animal Production and Health Paper|issue=95|pages=111–125|year=1992|url=http://www.fao.org/Ag/AGA/AGAP/FRG/AHPP95/95-111.pdf|accessdate=13 August 2010}}</ref>

==History== [[File:Albert_Eckhout_-_Mandioca.jpg|thumb|left|17th c. painting by [[Albert Eckhout]] in [[Dutch Brazil]]]] Wild populations of ''M. esculenta'' subspecies ''flabellifolia'', shown to be the progenitor of domesticated cassava, are centered in west-central Brazil, where it was likely first domesticated no more than 10,000 years [[Before Present|BP]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Olsen | first1 = KM | last2 = Schaal | first2 = BA | title = Evidence on the origin of cassava: phylogeography of ''Manihot esculenta'' | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 96 | issue = 10 | pages = 5586–91 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10318928 | pmc = 21904|bibcode = 1999PNAS...96.5586O |doi = 10.1073/pnas.96.10.5586 }}</ref> Forms of the modern domesticated species can also be found growing in the wild in the south of [[Brazil]]. By 4,600 BC, manioc (cassava) pollen appears in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] lowlands, at the [[San Andrés (Mesoamerican site)|San Andrés]] archaeological site.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1126/science.292.5520.1370|pmid=11359011|bibcode=2001Sci...292.1370P|title=Origin and Environmental Setting of Ancient Agriculture in the Lowlands of Mesoamerica|journal=Science|volume=292|issue=5520|pages=1370–3|last1=Pope|first1=Kevin O.|last2=Pohl|first2=Mary E. D.|last3=Jones|first3=John G.|last4=Lentz|first4=David L.|last5=von Nagy|first5=Christopher|last6=Vega|first6=Francisco J.|last7=Quitmyer|first7=Irvy R.|year=2001}}</ref> The oldest direct evidence of cassava cultivation comes from a 1,400-year-old [[Maya civilization|Maya]] site, [[Joya de Cerén]], in [[El Salvador]].<ref>[http://artsandsciences.colorado.edu/magazine/2009/06/cu-team-discovers-mayan-crop-system/ CU team discovers Mayan crop system] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715185525/http://artsandsciences.colorado.edu/magazine/2009/06/cu-team-discovers-mayan-crop-system/ |date=15 July 2015 }} University of Colorado at Boulder, 16 June 2009</ref> With its high food potential, it had become a [[staple food]] of the native populations of northern South America, southern Mesoamerica, and the Caribbean by the time of European contact in 1492. Cassava was a staple food of [[pre-Columbian]] peoples in the Americas and is often portrayed in [[Pre-Columbian art|indigenous art]]. The [[Moche (culture)|Moche]] people often depicted yuca in their ceramics.<ref>Berrin, Katherine & Larco Museum. ''The Spirit of Ancient Peru:Treasures from the [[Larco Museum|Museo Arqueológico Rafael Larco Herrera]].'' New York: [[Thames & Hudson]], 1997.</ref>
Spaniards in their early occupation of Caribbean islands did not want to eat cassava or maize, which they considered insubstantial, dangerous, and not nutritious. They much preferred foods from Spain, specifically wheat bread, olive oil, red wine, and meat, and considered maize and cassava damaging to Europeans. For these Christians in the [[New World]], cassava was not suitable for communion since it could not undergo [[transubstantiation]] and become the body of Christ. "Wheat flour was the symbol of Christianity itself" and colonial-era catechisms stated explicitly that only wheat flour could be used.<ref>Earle, Rebecca (2012) ''The Body of the Conquistador: Food, Race, and the Colonial Experience in Spanish America, 1492–1700''. New York: Cambridge University Press. pp. 54–57, 151. {{ISBN|978-1107693296}}.</ref>
The cultivation and consumption of cassava was nonetheless continued in both Portuguese and Spanish America. Mass production of cassava bread became the first Cuban industry established by the Spanish,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=Rn9LZ2XrIWgC&pg=PA75|title=Conquest and food: consequences of the encounter of two worlds; page 75|author=Long, Janet|publisher=UNAM|date=2003|isbn=978-9703208524}}</ref> Ships departing to Europe from Cuban ports such as [[Havana]], [[Santiago de Cuba|Santiago]], [[Bayamo]], and [[Baracoa]] carried goods to Spain, but sailors needed to be provisioned for the voyage. The Spanish also needed to replenish their boats with dried meat, water, fruit, and large amounts of cassava bread.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sjsu.edu/faculty/watkins/havana.htm|title=The Economic History of Havana, Cuba: A City So Beautiful and Important It Was Once Worth More Than All of Florida|author=Watkins, Thayer |publisher=San José State University, Department of Economics|date=2006}}</ref> Sailors complained that it caused them digestive problems.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Super, John C. |title=Spanish Diet in the Atlantic Crossing|journal=Terra Incognita|volume= 16 |year=1984|pages=60–63}}</ref> Tropical Cuban weather was not suitable for wheat planting and cassava would not go stale as quickly as regular bread.
Cassava was introduced to Africa by Portuguese traders from Brazil in the 16th century. Around the same period, it was also introduced to Asia through [[Columbian Exchange]] by Portuguese and Spanish traders, planted in their colonies in Goa, Malacca, Eastern Indonesia, Timor and the Philippines. [[Maize]] and cassava are now important staple foods, replacing native African crops.<ref>{{cite book|author=Nweke, Felix I. |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/009/a0154e/A0154E02.HTM |chapter=The cassava transformation in Africa|publisher=The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations |place=Rome|year= 2005|title=A review of cassava in Africa with country case studies on Nigeria, Ghana, the United Republic of Tanzania, Uganda and Benin|series =Proceedings of the Validation Forum on the Global Cassava Development Strategy| volume =Vol. 2}}</ref> Cassava has also become an important staple in Asia, extensively cultivated in Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam.<ref>{{Cite book|author=Hershey, Clair et al.|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/009/y1177e/Y1177E02.htm|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|title=A review of cassava in Asia with country case studies on Thailand and Viet Nam|chapter=Cassava in Asia. Expanding the Competitive Edge in Diversified Markets|place=Rome|date= April 2000}}</ref> Cassava is sometimes described as the "bread of the tropics"<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Adams | first1 = C. | last2 = Murrieta | first2 = R. | last3 = Siqueira | first3 = A. | last4 = Neves | first4 = W. | last5 = Sanches | first5 = R. | title = Amazon Peasant Societies in a Changing Environment| chapter = Bread of the Land: the Invisibility of Manioc in the Amazon | doi = 10.1007/978-1-4020-9283-1_13 | pages = 281–305| year = 2009| isbn = 978-1-4020-9282-4 }}</ref> but should not be confused with the tropical and equatorial [[bread tree]] ''(Encephalartos)'', the [[breadfruit]] ''(Artocarpus altilis)'' or the [[African breadfruit]] ''(Treculia africana)''.
==Production== In 2016, global production of cassava root was 277 million [[tonne]]s, with [[Nigeria]] as the world's largest producer having 21% of the world total (table). Other major growers were [[Thailand]], [[Brazil]], and [[Indonesia]].<ref name=faostat16/>
